review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
I don't usually flip reviews from bad to good, but here goes. Finding the scrolls in the right order gives you a more meaningful if still slightly confusing sense of Buddhism. In the wrong order they can come off as dark or depressing because they are out of context. 

Unfortunately, I got extreme VR sickness the first couple of plays on my Oculus Rift. Sometimes odd angles and the rapid spin my overly responsive gamepad gave can do that. So I tried the Win 7 fix. It certainly adjusted the height, but then the game would not display on my Rift though I could have played it on the screen.

Happily, seeing the kitsune made me clever because I sort of cobbled together using the keyboard to move and jump and the left controller to steer. It isn't a bad fix and since I'm flying I went with the idea of being a clever messenger fox for Inari. 

It is a really pretty game and a sort of mind no mind type of pointless wander and ponder, but it is still buggy. If the bugs could be fixed, like falling through the cave floor, and the pretty music extended to cover bigger areas of the map that would be awesome.

I liked the night  landscape and it seems like the devs did add things like stars and fish after being asked. The kitsune foxes and spirit tigers were cute and it was nice to see the other animals such as deer and rabbits return. Also happy to see the tori gates back. Any game that has so many things that remind me of Inari brings a smile to my face.

Maybe since Buddhism is in the series a game about his life or the religion in general?

review:
Heaven Forest NIGHTS is a VR simulator of walking through the forest and learning about life and death.

[h1] I don't own a VR set, but from just playing the game, I can give an accurate enough description of what the game offers. [/h1]

This game lets you walk through Heaven Forest, but now at night. If you've played or seen Heaven Forest - VR MMO, this game is almost identical to it. The only other differences are that it takes place in the nighttime, the scriptures are different, and there are some tigers instead of dear. The thing that baffles me is how this isn't just some DLC for Heaven Forest - VR MMO instead of them choosing to make it a whole other game when clearly it's basically the same game.

This game suffers from the same problems as the one just mentioned as well as this is a duplicate game that's labeled as a separate game, so I don't recommend this game.

review:
I would say I'm fairly religous myself, and I did somewhat like the teachings, but man... it was so frustrating to walk/fly around the map. And the ironic thing is the teaching talks about purpose, but wheres the purpose in the actual game?
I genuinely paid attention to what this game wants to say and I collected all items I could encounter and got all the flying orbs, but GOD I WAS DISAPPOINTED! THERE IS NO ENDING TO THIS GAME!  

I guess one thing i recommend this game doing is Instead of giving players the freedom to get to any part of the scrolls they should at least order it so that it's more interesting. Like for example, some players could read positive scrolls first and then end up with reading rest of the more dark feeling scrolls later which could leave a bitter impression. But putting an ending would be the best because it gives the developer a chance to be able to summarize the content. So even if some players have a hard time understanding some of the teachings you could be more down to earth to explain it and use more spoken words. 

Sorry but i'll give this game a 3/10

review:
Yes, I got a key for this game for free. Just like I did for it's predecessor. During one of the Dev's many "Throw keys to everyone!!!" sprees in Steam, Giveaway groups.

So, why am I not recomending a free game?

Because it is a reskin on the last Heaven Forest game, same terrible tech demo. NOT a game. A terrible tech demo. 
Same map, the color of the sky was changed, some of the animals went from color to grey scale, and a B & W tiger was added. Whoopie.

The animals still have horrid animation (rabbit looks like it sat on a plug and can't get it unstuck from it's rear...), animals path horribly (up sheer faces, stuck running in one place or doing small circles, etc.), You can fall though building floors and roofs (going up or down), collectables are in the exact same spots, a few are in areas you have to fidget for ages to get them to sparkle so you can collect them, flying is still broken (you may get stuck flying up but have no ability to move from left, right, back or forward, and you may not be able to do the "float down" thing, unless you manage to find an invisible wall to fly into and break the leash...), graphics are terrible, yet will heat your GPU and CPU up, no matter what settings you try, 2/3 D (2D that tries to looklike 3D and fails)...

Honestly, it is like all of his "games" They are all terribe tech demos. Trying to use some religious or philosophical messaging to make them seem interesting. It's like putting on a VR headset and being surrounded by Moonies trying to shove flowers in your face. Seems, harmess, until it happens. Then, it is a painful, horrifying, headache and nausea inducing ride you are trapped on.

No. Not worth it, Not paid, not free. Trading cards do exist, but take forever to get the 5/10 to drop, if you are lucky enough to get 5 different ones.  See my hours played. That's how long. Achievements? Yeah, not too hard to get, if you can keep from vomiting (in VR or on a flat screen) while you watch the entire world pop in and despawn, pop in again, despawn, pop in again... OUCH.  The TC's have little value. The achievements do not have notification pop-ups via Steam Overlay. They only unlock after you quit the game, and the Steam hook will unlock them all at the same time. So you never know how far your have progressed, and your achievement history makes it look like you are SAM's best friend, even if you aren't.

Dude, I get that you have a dream, But please. After torturing people with the Heaven series games and the equally awful Woodle Tree game... please stop. I BEG OF YOU. P{LEASE JUST STOP.   :spazhorror:

review:
Absolute treat
Do you like games like CoD, WoW, LoL? move along, there is nothing for you here
Unless... you are looking for a game to wind down and just plain relax, keep reading. This review covers for both the Heaven Forest titles
Heaven Forest NIGHTS is a walking simulator or as I call it a "relax simulator" Upio are walking through a beautiful sculpted world filled with different kind of animals. There is nothing for you to do but walk and pick up apples, mushrooms and a few gems.... if you want, if you do not want to pick them up that is ok as well. They are for a few achievements but have no purpose in the game itself as far as I can see.

What can you do?  .... walk.... that is it

Soooooo ... Mava .... why are you giving a thumbs up for a game in which you do nothing?
well.... looks, sound... they are great. It looks like the dev is still wanting to update this with more content so who knows what the future holds. It is a nice starter game for VR if you have it as it costs hardly anything and come on... a gaame about relaxing and finding the meaning of life... that is just awesome

review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title:[/b]  Heaven Forest NIGHTS
[b]Status:[/b]  Released
[b]Developer:[/b]  Fabio Ferrara
[b]Publisher:[/b]  Chubby Pixel
[b]Genre:[/b]  3D Adventure
[b]Release Date:[/b]  13th of March, 2017
[b]Type:[/b]  Singleplayer & Multiplayer

[h1]General Impression[/h1]
Since 2015, there have been four games in Fabio Ferrara‚Äô Heaven series. This is my second review for one of his creations, after Woodle Tree 2: Worlds. This developer‚Äôs games are far from the ‚Äúlow-effort‚Äù label some haters and trolls would have you believe. First and foremost, all those foaming around their mouths after such affordable titles, miss the crucial point here. They couldn‚Äôt code or design a game even if their lives would depend on it. Case dismissed.

On the contrary, given what they cost, such games have a niche of their own on Steam. Couple that with the fact that so many of these well-priced games host massive public giveaways, you can imagine that they‚Äôll reach an ever wider audience. Believe it or not, about one year ago I was more than happy and grateful for ANY free game I might gain in a public Gleam giveaway since I had a Steam game collection of close to 100. Before you disrespect someone‚Äôs hard work perhaps think for a second that not everybody on Steam can afford  to pay 60 dollars for a newly released AAA title? Some modesty wouldn‚Äôt hurt one bit, no matter how much spare cash you got at your disposal just for gaming.

Heaven Forest NIGHTS might not have changed much from it‚Äôs ‚Äúdaylight‚Äù version in the form of Heaven Forest - VR MMO but some minor tweaks have been applied to the fauna and flora. The core gameplay has you exploring a faily big open level in search for collectibles (mushrooms, crystals, souls, apples and quatrefoils) while you can read floating scrolls filled with metaphors and wise sayings. Those written words may not belong to Confucius or Lao Tzu, yet they still represent food for thought. Buddhism seems to be a central theme in the entire Heaven franchise since giant statues of the Buddha, can be found in all four titles. I may be closer to agnosticism than anything else, but at least I respect other people‚Äôs cultures and beliefs. Religion isn‚Äôt being promoted per se in this game which seems to focus more on Asian archtectural motifs.

Animals are also present on the map and roam freely. They don‚Äôt seem to even notice your presence and thus no combat/killing in this game. I hope you don‚Äôt regret that. In fact you appear to be controlling an essence or spirit more than a materialized character. You can levitate and thus explore Heaven Forest NIGHTS with increased efficiency. It‚Äôs a relaxing game that must be treated precisely like that. There‚Äôs no hidden meaning behind anything and what you see is what you get. I was more annoyed by the contrast between low-res textures near objects that were very skillfully textured and the constant pop-in of objects as if I was playing this game on my PS3 or something. At least the Unity Engine assets deliver 4K resolution and stable 60 fps without a single crash to desktop. Unreal Engine 4 has left a sour taste in my mouth because of its poor implementation in Steam indie games. At least you don‚Äôt have that stress in Heaven Forest NIGHTS.

As long as you keep an open mind and understand its low production value is being reflected in the equally low price tag, all will be well. And relax while playing it since that‚Äôs its intended purpose anyways. It may have full VR support, but I‚Äôm still a couple of years away from owning such a headset. Perhaps you might be more interested in these (still) overpriced gadgets but even without VR, the game is fully playable on a monitor and mouse+keyboard setup. You have Cards and Achievements too and all you have to do is buy it now or wait for a bundle or giveaway. Just show some common sense and gratitude if you received the game for free, ok?

[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Relaxing gameplay and sounds.
+ Decently priced for what it offers.
+ Virtual Reality headset support.
+ Steam Achievements & Trading Cards.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- A brief experience.
- Several low-res textures and the occasional pop-in objects.

[b]Rating 70/100 [/b]
